page.title: 04UPHAM CHURCH BELLS
page.content: Although there was a church in Upham as early as the thirteenth century, it is not known whether there were any bells in it then. Certainly the church had a peal of bells in the sixteenth century and in 1761 these were replaced by six bells cast from copper and tin by Thomas Swaine in a field near Alresford. In 1978 the wooden supporting frame had rotted, so the bells were removed. A new steel frame was erected by local helpers and two more bells added to make an octave. The first peal of the eight bells was rung in December 1979, being 5088 changes of Yorkshire S.Major. The captain of the bell ringers was Walter Stubbington from 1921 until 1978 and now his son Christopher has succeeded him.
